title.narrative: BRAC Studies: SRHR of PWDS and Male Youth in Banqladesh

description.narrative: Every individual, both male and female, has the right to make their own choices regarding Sexual and Reproductive Health and Rights (SRHR). The issue of inclusive SRHR has been reflected across many of the 17 Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), specifically SDGs 3, 4 and 5. However, evidence shows that SRHR aspects of male youth are traditionally ignored, even more for persons with disabilities (PWDs). This picture is not very different in Bangladesh. There is a lack of research and data relevant to SRHR knowledge, perceptions and practices of PWDs and male youth in Bangladesh. As a result, SRH sufferings of the vulnerable groups and ways to reach them and provide adequate and appropriate services to improve their SRHR situation is largely unknown. There is also a shortage of evidence regarding the barriers and bottlenecks of ensuring proper implementation of laws and policies relevant to SRHR. All the evidence points towards the fact that there are no comprehensive studies available that illustrate a holistic picture of PWDs and/or male youth and their SRHR needs, perceptions, and gaps and challenges in programs and policies. Contemplating the significance of the issue, the “SRHR of PWDs and Male Youth in Bangladesh” research studies is being funded by the Embassy of the Kingdom of the Netherlands, and implemented by BRAC James P Grant School of Public Health (BRAC JPGSPH), BRAC University.
Persons with disabilities and male youth

The studies will produce solid evidence on SRHR knowledge, needs, perceptions, beliefs and behaviors of PWDs and male youth along with information on gaps in interventions, required SRH services, and policies. • The evidence generated will be useful in the near future to design appropriate and inclusive SRH programmes and services for the two vulnerable population groups: PWDs and male youth. • Multiple outputs (journal articles, research reports, policy briefs, newspaper articles in Bengali and English, blogs and video documentaries) and dissemination activities (policy dialogues, roundtable discussions, national dissemination events) will encourage national, regional and global debates on ensuring the need for better programmes and policies related to the SRHR of PWDs and male youth in Bangladesh and neighboring countries.

The ‘SRHR of persons with disabilities (PWDs) Project’ has the following objectives: • Objective 1- To understand SRHR needs, knowledge about SRHR, SRH sufferings, perceptions around sex and sexuality and barriers in accessing SRH services for PWDs in Bangladesh through primary research • Objective 2- Secondary review of existing interventions and/or services relevant to SRHR of PWDs, identify gaps in currently implementing interventions and/or services, and recommend strategies to improve delivery of interventions and/or services • Objective 3- Review existing laws and policies relevant to SRHR and disability in Bangladesh and explore barriers to implementation of laws and policies and recommend strategies for improvement. The ‘SRHR of Male Youth Project’ has the following objectives: • Objective 1 - Identify SRHR needs, knowledge, perceptions of male youth in Bangladesh • Objective 2 - Review the existing SRHR interventions for male youth and identify the gaps and challenges to improve SRHR interventions and/or services. • Objective 3 - Review existing policies regarding SRH for male youth and identify the barriers of implementation in programs and recommendations for policy advocacy.

activity-date.narrative: The planned end date for the project is on 15th May 2020
The planned start date for the project was on 1st November, 2018
The project got a budget-neutrally extension for seven months. The revised duration of the project is 15 November, 2018 to 15 December, 2020
The project officially started its operation on 15th November, 2018.

recipient-country.narrative: The project is implemented across the whole country.

title.narrative: The Story of Sholoshohor Rail Station
The other side of the coin: Unanswered questions of men’s sexuality
The Story of Sholoshohor Rail Station

description.narrative: National poet, the great Kazi Nazrul Islam, penned his perspectives on age and youth in his critically acclaimed article ‘Joiboner Gann (Song of the Youth).’ “And I have seen many old men whose glowing youth shines like the sun beneath the ripeness of old age.” I along with one of my colleagues from BRAC James P Grant School of Public Health, BRAC University went to Sholoshohor rail station, Chattogram for a research study titled- Male Youth and their Sexual and Reproductive Health and Rights (SRHR) in Bangladesh, targeting 15 to 24-year-old male youths. We spent thirty days in and around the rail station — from dawn to dusk — in order to explore the SRHR knowledge, behaviour, and practices of young males. Within a few days of observation, I realized that this particular station is completely different from all the other rail stations in the country. It is old indeed but parallelly it is young. Here I try to present a cross-sectional story of the station. Established in 1931, Sholoshohor rail station is so old that one will find it very difficult to discover the nameplate of the station. However, it is a youth hub, not like typical inter-district railway stations or junctions. In fact, there is no inter-district train movement from the station. There are only a few train trips from Chattogram to Dohazari, and the famous shuttle train of the University of Chittagong enters and leaves the station. It soon became clear that transporting university students from the centre of a major city corporation is what gave Sholoshohor rail station its unique characteristics. The rail station is situated just 50–60 meters away from Sholoshohor bus stand. There are four rooms in the whole station — one for the station master, one for the rail police, one for ticket distribution, and the other, well, it remains closed at all times and so, no one knows what it is for. There is an old foot over-bridge in the station and also a mosque. Towards the north side of the station lie abandoned red-ochre-coloured compartments, 40–50 in number. Seven or eight of these compartments have no doors and they remain open. Anybody can enter these rooms at will. I found foil papers, weed remains, and other wastes related to drug consumption in those compartments. Household wastes spontaneously pile up in front and behind the station. Even the railroad track boards can be found lying here and there in the eastern and western corners inside the station. There are twenty shops scattered around the platform and among them, four or five are really well-decorated with plants, chairs and tables, et cetera. Different fruit juices, flavoured teas, local snacks, coffee, and other street foods can be found in these shops. There is a popular food item named ‘mixture’ which is indeed a mixture of available street foods. Photo: Author So, why is this station different from other rail stations in the country? Usually, rail stations are busy and chaotic. Everyone is always in a hurry to leave the station as early as possible, especially in Bangladesh where the trains are notorious for their delayed timing. Nobody even dares to spend an extra bit of time here. This particular rail station is different from the others in this very sense. As few trains pass this station, the hustle is comparatively less here. From early morning till late at night, students from different institutions gather around Sholoshohor rail station. Different groups have different agendas to discuss. The anthropologists talk passionately about gender equality and equity, students of business studies have practical discussions about accounting, some have heated debates on national and international political issues, some sing without a care in the world, while some plan out political activities. Some practice their performances for an upcoming play while some remain glued to their mobile phone screens. Even the school-going kids end up coming here, following the university seniors. And surprisingly, the male-to-female ratio is almost proportional. The local youths are not lagging behind either. They take over the tea stall tables, especially after the evening, when they return from their workplace and join in the daily discussions. Local politics, love, sports, Tiktok videos, and other daily activities become the focus of discussions. Their modern-day styles of attire and demeanour are obvious. They literally try to mimic the hairstyles, beards, clothes, and tattoos of their sports idols, favourite movie stars, and other celebrities. Looking at the outward appearance of male youths, one will not be able to differentiate between the local boys and the university boys. Photo: Faisal The station gets more interesting after the evening. This is when it becomes difficult for an outsider to differentiate this rail station from a university campus. Shops are decorated with colourful lights, and students swarm the station, either singing or studying together. Some discuss random subjects while some play cards. Some come here with their significant other to spend quality time. Even the foot over-bridge is taken over by young men. Some boys can be seen sitting on wooden planks with groups of friends, smoking cigarettes and chatting away. One can also smell drugs if he or she walks by the rail line. Photo: Author Some hawkers sell second-hand mobile phones in front of the station. Towards the south side of the bridge, a kabiraj can be seen selling “rings of luck”. There are sellers of watches and cheap clothes, and street foods like peanuts, fuchka, chotpoti and other popular snacks. Homeless people can be seen quarrelling with one other — fighting over space to sleep. The only things louder than the commotion in the vegetable market are the loudspeakers used by shopkeepers to play Tamil or Hindi movies. In short, the station during this time bursts to life. The passengers take preparations for departure when they hear announcements but the funny thing here is, nobody needs tickets except the passengers of Chattogram-Dohazari route. The university shuttle — in a never-ending cycle — brings and takes away batches of students from the station. Roaming around this station night and day for one month, I had the opportunity to interact with the university students and local youths simultaneously. They said that this station works as a hub linking the city and the university. The local youths believed this station to be their lifeline. Their friend circles, romantic relationships, and daily chit-chats all converge at this rail station. Photo: Nagarphool Every Friday, a youth volunteer organization named ‘Nagarphool’ (urban flower) teach unprivileged children on the northern platform of the station. The children also sing the national anthem together after their studies. Even other people sing with them. The whole station then takes on an image of a school. Another volunteer youth organization called ‘Bidyananda’ distributes food to unprivileged children for one taka only. This famous project is called ‘Ek takay ahar’ (food for one taka). The menu consists of sumptuous meals: khichuri, chicken, vegetable, pulao, etc. Children can be seen taking food, waiting diligently in queues in a disciplined manner, at least once a week. Sholoshohor rail station is an interesting case study of the wide variety of interests and activities that appeal to young men of today. It not only reflects an unbiased picture of male youth’s vibrant energy and their need for social connection but also the kinds of activities and risk-taking behaviour young men in urban centres in Bangladesh tend to indulge in. The story of Sholoshohor rail station goes to show the spontaneous emergence of spaces of recreation that the young generation of today is clearly in need of. This is where groups of young men — hailing from diverse socioeconomic backgrounds — come together to spend their leisure time. This unique rail station depicts the reality of the current generation of male youths in the country. Abdul Jabbar Topu is a Senior Field Coordinator at BRAC James P Grant School of Public Health, BRAC University. Acknowledgements: Dr Sabina Faiz Rashid, Farzana Misha, Syed Hassan Imtiaz, Nahela Nowshin.

title.narrative: A ‘Core Advocacy Group’ was formed for the SRHR of PWDs study

description.narrative: A core advisory committee was formed and the first advisory committee meeting was organized on 31st October, 2019. The advisory panel consisted of experts from prominent development, health, and policy sectors. During the meeting, the JPGSPH research team presented the preliminary research findings of the quantitative survey, intervention mapping and policy landscape. The advisory committee shared their insights on the initial findings and progress of the project. Series of discussions helped to redefine the future activities for the project and was expected to strengthen the upcoming policy dialogues with the government.

title.narrative: A core advisory committee was formed and the advisory panel consisted of experts from prominent development, health, and policy sectors.
Advisory Steering Committee for the SRHR for Male Youth Study

description.narrative: A core advisory group was formed to ensure quality assurance, establish networks and partnerships for effective dissemination, and strategize advocacy of the project. The committee consists of eight members, which includes academics, NGO and government personnel, and development practitioners.

title.narrative: The first Advisory Steering Committee meeting.

description.narrative: The first Advisory Steering Committee meeting was held on 26th August 2019 at the Dean’s Conference room, BRAC JPGSPH. In the first Advisory Steering Committee Meeting, the team presented its research and analysis plan and received constructive reviews and feedback from the members. These were later incorporated in the research plan. In total, there were 23 participants during the meeting.

title.narrative: Pictorial booklet on Inherent Burdens of Disability and Moving Ahead of It

description.narrative: A pictorial booklet has been made by the research team which shares the findings of the research across the themes of stigma, neglect and abuse. Both quantitative and qualitative findings were incorporated in the booklet, with special presentations of a few case stories. The booklet also discussed about the way to move forward and proposed multiple recommendations on the issues of stigma, abuse and neglect that persons with disabilities face. The booklet has been designed using vector art medium, in a visually captivating manner to attract audience from a younger age group. The booklet has been colour printed for further use and both multimedia and braille versions are produced to make it disability friendly.

title.narrative: Pictorial booklet on Inherent Burdens of Disability and Moving Ahead of It
Policy infographic entitled Current Situation of SRHR of Persons with Disabilities in Bangladesh in the Context of SDGs and UNCRPD

description.narrative: A policy infographic entitled Current Situation of SRHR of Persons with Disabilities in Bangladesh in the Context of SDGs and UNCRPD, has been published by the research team that focuses on the overall SRHR situation of the persons with disabilities in Bangladesh, barriers and facilitators to reach UNCRPD and SDG goals in relation to SRHR and Persons with disabilities. As part of the dissemination activities and to broadcast in a wider network, the infographic was published in JPGSPH website and social media platform. In addition, it was printed in normal format, braille format and in multimedia voice projection as an audio book, in order to ensure inclusivity and to reach the actual beneficiary groups of different types of persons with disabilities.

title.narrative: Disability-&-SRHR_2nd-Policy-Dialogue-Infographic-book-4-January-2021-20210307080347.pdf
Policy infographic titled "Current Situation of SRHR of Persons with Disabilities in Bangladesh in the Context of SDGs and UNCRPD”
Policy infographic entitled Inclusive Health Services for Persons with Disabilities in Bangladesh: Challenges and Prospects

description.narrative: A policy infographic entitled Inclusive Health Services for Persons with Disabilities in Bangladesh: Challenges and Prospects, has been published by the research team that focuses on the overall situation of SRH services, existing facilitators and barriers, and key recommendations to improve the SRH services and outcomes for persons with disabilities in Bangladesh. It briefly highlighted the key facts and figures regarding the SRH of persons with disabilities based on the availability, accessibility, affordability and quality (AAAQ) framework of World Health Organization (WHO). As part of the dissemination activities and to broadcast in a wider network, the infographic was published in JPGSPH website and social media platform. In addition, it was printed in normal format, braille format and in multimedia voice projection as an audio book, in order to ensure inclusivity and to reach the actual beneficiary groups of different types of persons with disabilities.

title.narrative: Disability-&-SRHR_1st-Policy-infographic-book_Final-20210307070345.pdf
Policy infographic titled “Inclusive Health Services for Persons with Disabilities in Bangladesh: Challenges and Prospects”
Oral presentation in international conference

description.narrative: A team member from the project presented an abstract in the 4th World Disability and Rehabilitation Conference, 2019 organized by the International Institute of Knowledge Management (TIIKM) which took place in Bangkok, Thailand on 7-8 November, 2019. The title of the paper was “Documenting the Challenges of Conducting Research on Sexual and Reproductive Health & Rights (SRHR) of Persons with Disabilities: Lessons from Bangladesh.” The main theme of the paper was to present field challenges experienced by the research team while conducting this research and the strategies adopted to resolve those challenges so one can do research in a sensitive and a methodical manner for young people and adults living with disabilities.

title.narrative: Presenting an abstract in the Disability & Rehabilitation Conference (Bangkok) held in November 2019

description.narrative: A team member from the project presented an abstract in the 4th World Disability and Rehabilitation Conference, 2019 organized by the International Institute of Knowledge Management (TIIKM) which took place in Bangkok, Thailand on 7-8 November, 2019.

title.narrative: Presenting abstract based on study findings in national/international conferences
Infographic policy brief on male youth and their SRHR in Bangladesh

description.narrative: An Infographic policy brief has been developed on 15-24 years old male youth in Bangladesh. The infographic was divided into four sections, one for each objective and a number of recommendations. Under the first objective, it focused on SRRHR knowledge, practice, perception, health-seeking behaviour, daily activities and use of technology, risk-taking behaviour, attitude towards women and masculinity and gender roles. Under Objective 2 it mapped out the types of interventions and services available in Bangladesh. This also included implementation challenges from both the demand and supply side. Under the last objective, it descried the findings from reviewing the existing national policies, SRHR laws and national curriculum. Finally, it provided a number of recommendations.

title.narrative: Male youth and their Sexual and Reproductive Health and Rights (SRHR) in Bangladesh: A mixed Methods Nationwide Study
Infographic on Male Youth and their SRHR in Bangladesh
Poster presentation in an international conference

description.narrative: An abstract has been accepted for Poster presentation at the 10th Asia Pacific Conference on Reproductive and Sexual Health and Rights in the following category: Track 3, SRHR for adolescents and young people / Sub-theme C, SRHR programming for adolescents and youth: What works? (3C)

title.narrative: Male-youth-related SRHR interventions in Bangladesh: Challenges of program implementation
Dissemination of key findings in one international conference
Policy advocacy workshop - Promoting Sexual and Reproductive Health and Rights of Male Youths (15-24 years) in Bangladesh: Challenges and Opportunities

description.narrative: An online Policy Dialogue Workshop was organized on 30 November, 2020, titled “Promoting Sexual and Reproductive Health and Rights of Male Youths (15-24 years) in Bangladesh: Challenges and Opportunities” to share and discuss research findings from the study. In this webinar, Subas Biswas (Senior Research Fellow), Dr. Farzana A. Misha (Research Coordinator), and Professor Dr. Sabina Faiz Rashid (Dean) from BRAC JPGSPH shared the research findings. The panel discussion was participated by Dr. Md. Jaynal Haque (Program Manager, Adolescent and Reproductive Health, DGFP), Syed Mahfooz Ali (Senior Specialist, Curriculum Wing, NCTB), and Dr. Bellal Hossain (Professor, Population Science, University of Dhaka). Ministry of Health and Family Welfare’s Public Health Expert Advisor, Dr. Abu Jamil Faisel participated as the special guest and Shahan Ara Banu (Director General, Directorate General of Family Planning) joined as the chief guest. Other government officials, researchers, and development workers from renowned and grassroots organizations and journalists participated in the session. This program news was covered by several daily news portal and newspapers.

title.narrative: Brac JPGSPH organises workshop on Promoting Sexual, Reproductive Health, Rights of Male Youths
Brac JPGSPH organises workshop on Promoting Sexual, Reproductive Health, Rights of Male Youths
Journalist Orientation Workshop on SRHR for male youth

description.narrative: An online workshop was held with journalists on 29 October 2020 from 3 PM to 4:30 PM. The researchers shared and discuss with journalists about the research findings of SRHR issues, gaps, and challenges in health services, GNGO interventions and government policies and laws related to male SRHR with prospective recommendations followed by a discussion.

title.narrative: Journalist Orientation Workshop on SRHR for male youth

description.narrative: Journalist Orientation Workshop on SRHR for male youth

title.narrative: Journalist Orientation Workshop on SRHR for male youth
Brainstorming workshops with government and non-government stakeholders.

description.narrative: BRAC JPGSPH research team organized two brainstorming workshops for the SRHR of PWDs study. The first workshop was held on 23rd April, 2019 at BRAC JPGSPH premises, and government officials from different departments and academics from BRAC University and Dhaka University attended the workshop. The second workshop was held on 25th April, 2019 at BRAC JPGSPH premises and representatives from INGOs/NGOs and DPOs attended the workshop. The purposes of the workshops were to get feedback on study design and tools, discuss priority areas for research, and strategies for policy advocacy.

title.narrative: 4 government officials and 2 academics attended the 1st workshop on 23rd April 2019. A total of 6 NGO/DPO professionals attended the 2nd workshop on 25th April, 2019.
Two policy dialogues with key policy makers were organized between October 2020 and November 2020 to promote SRHR of persons with disabilities in Bangladesh

description.narrative: Considering the COVID-19 pandemic situation and prioritizing health of all, two policy dialogues were organized virtually, engaging key policy makers and policy implementers from different ministries of the Government of Bangladesh, NGO health care providers, health system and SRHR experts of the country. 1st policy dialogue workshop was organized on October 27, 2020 with more than 70 participants attended. It focused on "Inclusive Health Service for Persons with Disabilities in Bangladesh: Challenges and Prospects". 2nd policy dialogue workshop was organized on 23rd November 2020, with more than 90 participants attended. It focused on “Promoting sexual and reproductive health and rights (SRHR) of persons with disabilities in Bangladesh in the context of SDGs and UNCRPD”.

title.narrative: Two policy dialogues with key policy makers were organized between October 2020 and November 2020 to promote SRHR of persons with disabilities in Bangladesh
Newspaper articles in national English and Bangla newspapers

description.narrative: The first journalist workshop on disability and SRHR was organized on 28th October, 2019. As a follow up activity, three of the largest circulating newspapers of the country, Prothom Alo, Dhaka Tribune and New Age published articles about Disability and SRHR in their newspapers the following day, 29th October, 2019. The workshop was reported and also awareness about disability and SRHR issues were highlighted.

title.narrative: Reproductive health of people with disabilities overlooked
Sexual, reproductive health rights of people with disabilities neglected
Three of the largest circulating newspapers of Bangladesh, Prothom Alo, Dhaka Tribune and New Age published articles about Disability and SRHR on 29th October, 2019.
First sensitization training for journalists on writing about disability and SRHR issues

description.narrative: The first sensitization training for journalists on writing about disability and SRHR issues was organized on 28th October, 2019. Journalists from the leading Bangla and English newspapers and print media organizations of the country, for example: Prothom Alo, New Age, Shomokal, Bhorer Kagoj, Noyadigonto and Dhaka Tribune attended the workshop.

title.narrative: The first sensitization training for journalists on writing about disability and SRHR issues was organized on 28th October, 2019.
Fact Sheet: Male Youth and their Sexual and Reproductive Health in Bangladesh: A Mixed Methods Nationwide Study

description.narrative: The project report will provide evidence from the nationally representative study, where, both qualitative and quantitative evidence are presented to understand the sexual and reproductive health status (SRH) of male youth (15–24 years). Quantitative and qualitative findings will provide an extensive picture of their knowledge, perceptions, behaviour and experiences around SRH, which includes puberty, social norms, sex & sexuality, masculinity and SRH rights. Successive chapters document existing government and non-government organizational SRH services in Bangladesh, and the implementation challenges that exist through data collected from stakeholders. This is followed by a review of existing SRH policies for male youth; reviewing laws, policies and national curricula to explore policy gaps in law, service provision and education.

title.narrative: Fact Sheet: Male Youth and their Sexual and Reproductive Health in Bangladesh: A Mixed Methods Nationwide Study
Fact Sheet: Male Youth and their Sexual and Reproductive Health in Bangladesh: A Mixed Methods Nationwide Study
National Dissemination Event on SRHR of persons with disabilities and male youth in Bangladesh

description.narrative: The virtual national dissemination event of the research project was organized on Tuesday, 15 December, 2020 from 10:00 am to 12:00 pm along with “SRHR of persons with disabilities and male youth in Bangladesh” to share and discuss research findings from the study. In this event, Dr. Farzana Misha (Research Coordinator) shared the research findings of ‘Male Youth and their Sexual and Reproductive Health and Rights (SRHR) in Bangladesh: A Mixed-Methods Nationwide study’. As special guests, Md. Anisuzzaman, Managing Director (Additional Secretary), National Foundation for Development of the Disabled Persons, Ministry of Social Welfare, Government of the People's Republic of Bangladesh; a representative from the Dutch Embassy in Dhaka, Embassy of the Kingdom of the Netherlands in Bangladesh and as Ms Sahan Ara Banu, NDC, Director General, Directorate General of Family Planning, Health Education and Family Welfare Division, Ministry of Health and Family Welfare, Government of the People's Republic of Bangladesh were present as Chief guest in this session, participated in the discussion and gave their speech on the issues. K A M Morshed, Senior Director, Advocacy, Technology & Partnership of BRAC deliver closing remarks of this session.

title.narrative: National Dissemination Event on SRHR of persons with disabilities and male youth in Bangladesh
SRHR of persons with disabilities and male youth in Bangladesh
Video Documentary on SRHR for male youth in Bangladesh
Voices of Masculinity

description.narrative: The research team along with Magnifier Creatives and Dina Hossain and produced a short documentary titled “Voices of Masculinity in Bangladesh”. The team interviewed a number of study participants and in the midst of the pandemic and produced the eight-minute-long documentary. The documentary has been shared online and on several social media platforms. It has been well-received across different social groups as far as we have observed.

title.narrative: Video Documentary
